h5. Problem definition
Currently JIRA gadgets can only be moved on the page upon using drag and drop using a mouse or touchpad.

h5. Suggested Solution
Allow gadgets to be moved using keyboard keys.
fields.summary: Move dashboard gadgets using keyboard

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-46043].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
	As an admin I would like our users could reset the Filter Results gadget to its default filter ordering when the page is reloaded. Once we create this gadget and a user clicks to any column to sort, the default sort definded in the filter is gone and never comes back (since the user last columns sorting is saved).

h3. Suggested Solution
	Options to solve this problem:
	* A refresh of the gadgets page could reset the results in this gadget
	* A reset filter order option could be added to the gadget
	* The filter could have an option to block columns sorting
 
h3. Workaround
	The main field (used as the first field in the order by statement) used to order the filter results should always be presented as a column in the gadget. Once the user sorts the column with the correct field, the results will be sorted as defined in the filter.
fields.summary: Reset Filter Results gadget so it shows the results as ordered in the configured filter

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-46037].
  {panel}

As a user, it would be useful having the ability to upgrade the core of JIRA with a button directly from within the application similar to add-ons.

This would ensure that users are upgrading JIRA in a more efficient manner rather than the way it is currently done and it also reassures the users that there would be less issues when the upgrade is completed.

*Expected behaviour*
- Add a function to upgrade JIRA directly from within the application.

*Actual Behaviour*
- Users have to download an installer file and have to hope they are able to upgrade JIRA with no issues which is less reassuring.
fields.summary: Add feature to Upgrade JIRA within the JIRA Application

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

h3. Summary
The attachment button is not available when commenting in the same transition where attachment is uploaded to the issue.

h3. Environment
JIRA 7.0.0-OD-08-005

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Edit a screen to have attachment field and comment field
# Associate the screen with a workflow
# Transition the issue to the point where it will use the screen
# Add an attachment and upon commenting the attachment button is not available to be selected

h3. Expected Results
The attachment button is available and can be selected
h3. Actual Results
No attachment button is available
 
h3. Notes
The attachment button in comments will be available if there are existing attachments in the issue before the transition.

h3.Workaround
# Add attachment first, then in another screen add comment with embedded attachment.
# Drag and drop attachments to the comment field (the attachment will be uploaded and embedded into the comment)
fields.summary: Attachment button to embed attachment not available when commenting

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-46034].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
If a user uses unsupported environment and installs (or upgrades) JIRA on the server, the installation/upgrade finishes normally.

Currently, users need to refer to the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/supported-platforms-207488170.html] to determine is the environment is compatible. While some admins do this, some others might miss it and then only notice it when they run into issues.


h3. Suggested Solution
If unsupported environment (example database) is being used, then JIRA installer should stop as soon as it detects that giving a clear message to the user something like :
"You are using an unsupported database. Please change to a [supported|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/supported-platforms-207488170.html] database to proceed the installation."
fields.summary: JIRA automatic installer should throw error if an unsupported environment is being used

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-46033].
  {panel}

Today every tiny change a user does to a ticket emits an email notification. Only if you use the "edit" window you can reduce the flood. This is not good for anybody.

Suggestion:
1. Provide an option for "digest emails" which is ON by default, as opposed to direct.
2. Provide a few values for the delay: 1 and 10 minutes, and 1, 3, 6 and 12 hours.

The digest should be the "diff" between time 0 and 0+delay. Meaning: I change a bug assignee from Joe to myself, set it to In-Progress, and set back Joe as assignee ... the diff is from previous state to In-progress. It is not interesting to see the 3-step dance to be able to do that state change.

The digest should be per bug, not containing several bugs. If that is interesting it is another enhancement request, outside of the scope for this one.

The digest should probably not cover more than one user. Hence I guess the longer delays could be ignore and you only go for 1 and 10 minutes. Or even just 5 minutes.

The overall idea is to minimize the email flood for when updating one small things which must be done in several steps (such as when a non-assignee want to set a bug in-progress), or when updating a few small things, such as state, assignee, add-CC and maybe a comment, whereof all are logically just one batch.

Thanks in advance
Simon
fields.summary: Add options for digest email notifications to Jira

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, only the following condition will prevent user from getting deleted:
# reported or been assigned to any issues
# commented on any issues

Which means when the user does not fulfil any of the above condition however he/she added some worklog entry in a particular issue, the user will still be deleted when perform the user deletion action.

Example, when you remove the user in LDAP side, then resyn back to JIRA, user will be deleted instead of being shown as inactive.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great if these users will be shown inactive instead of deletion as due to certain preservation of that particular user effort in the issue he/she work on before.
fields.summary: restrict user deletion when user has worklog entry in JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-46013].
  {panel}

Please allow JIRA administrators to see private filters and dashboards in the GUI.
Some use cases: 
* A user created a filter, forgot to share it, sent the link by mail to some people who should use it, and ran off for holiday. Sure, the people who got the mails will complain. The adminstrator should be able to acces the filter in the GUI and to share it.
* People who leave the company do not delete their private filters and dashboards before they go. Over time, this relicts will pile up. Adminstrators should have the option to clear private filters and dashboards after a user has left.

It's not feasible to query the database to find out which private filters exist and who the owners are, and alter the database. 

First, functionalities in the GUI would be more convenient to use.
Second, you cannot assume that JIRA administrators have access to the database. In our company, I have to contact central administration and ask them if they could run queries and clean up which would be completely unnecessary if I had some more options in the GUI.

Regards, Evelin
fields.summary: JIRA administrators should be able to see private filters and dashboards

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-46007].
  {panel}

This has been floating around for many years by the look of it but I can't find an open version of it, so here I go!

Use case:

Our team is (attempting to be) Agile and hence we allow all team members to create issues and assign to whomever they think is appropriate (team members are supposed to be trusted and processes should allow quick reaction to change rather than hierarchies of assignment). Also, inspection of our database reveals that the assignee and reporter are the same for 84% of our issues, i.e. 84% of the time it is better to automatically assign to the reporter than require them to manually assign to themselves. Clearly, the process that will best suit us is to have the reporter as the default assignee and allow users to assign to someone else if need be (which will be the minority of the time).

Current workarounds:

1) There is an "assign to me" button which is obviously pretty quick to press. However, the fact that the apparent solution also seems very straightforward means that this is something people find very frustrating. Additionally, it is open to people forgetting (we trust our team members but also accept that they make mistakes).

2) A post function can be added to always assign to the current user. This is not great because it bulldozes over any actual selection the user makes (which will be very irritating 16% of the time for us) and is also not very visible/intuitive even when you do want it to happen (you have to leave the assignee field blank knowing that it is about to be assigned).

Proposal:

Add the option to make the reporter/current user the default assignee in a project.

Justification:

This is a completely null change to anyone not making use of it, the only people who would even notice it would be project admins/leads, who would only be exposed to an extra option in a drop down if they decided to configure the default assignee (which they would probably only be doing if they want this feature!). Whereas people like myself will benefit 84% of the time that we are creating a JIRA issue.
fields.summary: Add "Reporter" or "Current User" option to default assignee choices

h4. +Scenario+
In JIRA 6.4, attached images are displayed as thumbnails, while non-thumbnailable files are displayed in a list:
!jira645.png|thumbnail!

In JIRA 7, all files are either displayed as thumbnails or in a list, making it hard to differentiate among the file types:
!jira700.png|thumbnail!

h4. +Suggestion+
Attachment section in JIRA 7 should maintain the old layout as in JIRA 6.4

h4. +Notes+
# There's no new settings from JIRA Administration -> System -> Attachments to take control of the layout
# There's no difference in the *fileattachment* table in the database, in which a .pdf file is still non-thumbnailable and only images are thumbnailable
fields.summary: Attachment section in JIRA 7 does not separate thumbnailable from non-thumbnailable files

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a webhook to fire on all JIRA config changes, e.g. voting, watching, etc.  
2. Go into JIRA admin and change the voting from enabled to disabled or vice versa
3. Check the event fired by the webhook (I was using RequestBin). The webhookEvent property is set to 'option_watching_changed'. 

Expected results:
I would have thought that the webhookEvent should be set to 'option_voting_changed' or similar.

h3. Summary
The *Create Filter* link on the *Favorite Filters* gadget in JIRA redirects to an issue rather than staying on the Issue Navigator page if the user is on the *Detail View*

h3. Environment
{{JIRA v7.0.0-OD-08-002}}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a dashboard
# Make sure your Issue Navigator is set to use the *Detail View* rather than the *List View*
# Add the gadget *Favorite Filters*
# Click on the link *Create Filter*

h3. Expected Results
Redirects to Issue Navigator in order to create a new filter

h3. Actual Results
Redirects to Issue Navigator then to the first issue listed
 
h3.Workarounds
# Use the Issues link located at the top navigator bar
# Set the Issue Navigator to *List View*
fields.summary: Create Filter link on Favorite Filters gadget redirects to an issue

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45986].
  {panel}

When doing a Bulk change the actual limit is set by the *Page Size* value in the user Profile rather than by the values in _jira-config.properties_.

Please find attached some screenshots showing the behaviour.

These are our settings in _jira-config.properties_:
{code}
jira.bulk.edit.limit.issue.count = -1
jira.search.views.default.max = 3000
jira.search.views.max.limit = 3000
jira.search.views.max.unlimited.group = jira.power-searchers
{code}

As a result of this behaviour many users get confused as they see the message to bulk change all the issues but afterwards they're only able to apply the changes to a few of them.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Bulk edit limited by page size

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45985].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
If permissions in the JIRA home / data directory isn't correct (i.e. belongs to root:root instead of js-jira:js-apps, in the case of Cloud), then the user won't be able to toggle Attachments on. Non system admins may not even see the Edit button, as you can see in this screenshot:

!Screen Shot 2015-10-28 at 16.28.02.jpg|thumbnail!

h3. Environment
* JIRA 7.0.0-OD-08-002

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Navigate to Attachment settings at {{domain.atlassian.net//secure/admin/ViewAttachmentSettings.jspa}}, and click *Edit Settings* and toggle off all attachment settings.
# In the filesystem, break the permissions by recursively chowning the {{attachments/}} folder to root:root, for example. (Whatever would not give JIRA access to the files)

{noformat}drwxr-xr-x  4 js-jira js-apps 4096 Jul 29 19:18 .
drwxr-xr-x 11 js-jira js-apps 4096 Oct 26 06:44 ..
drwxr-xr-x  4 root    root    4096 Oct  2 19:58 attachments
drwxr-xr-x  2 js-jira js-apps 4096 Oct 22 14:54 avatars{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
# In a proper save, the screen closes itself, and the changes are applied.
# There should be some error saying the permissions are not correct, at least. Rather than not save.

h3. Actual Results
# Attempt to *Edit Settings* in the attachment settings again, this time enabling attachments. When you click *Update*, it will start to save, but return back to the same screen.
# No errors in the JIRA log.

h3. Workaround
Correct the permissions in both attachments and avatars folders recursively, so JIRA will have access to the files.

*Cloud customers* please contact support to have this done.
fields.summary: As an administrator, user is unable to enable attachments due to file permissions

h3. Problem Definition
When an administrator logs in as a different user, it gets a pop up window noticing that he's logged in as a different user. However, if the administrator has more tabs open (where he was logged with his admin account) and try to continue working as normal, he will get an error message instead of the pop-up window saying he's logged as a different user. The error says _"An unknown error has occurred trying to contact our servers, please try again. If the issue persists please raise a ticket with support."_

h3. Suggested Solution
Instead of the error message, it would be nice to have some kind of warning message stating that you are logged in as another user and cannot perform your usual tasks, because you no longer have the same access.

  {panel}

h3. Summary
Please make *Period* in JIRA Gadgets like (Resolution Time, Time Since Chart) more configurable.

h3. Actual Results
We have to choose 'Period' from following options
* Hourly
* Daily
* Weekly
* Monthly
* Quarterly
* Yearly
 
h3. Expected Results
Aside from the above options, we want an option to configure *Period* manually.
For example, we want to configure the beginning and the end of *Period*.

h3. Notes
Now, If we choose 'Yearly' option for *Period*, the beginning of the period is set to January automatically.
However, we sometimes want to use fiscal year than calendar year.
In such case, if we can configure the beginning of the period, it can be more useful for us.

h3. Problem

When a potential user clicks on a link to create an issue and is not logged in, they see the following message:

!Error_01.png!

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45963].
  {panel}

*Feature Summary*
As a user or JIRA Admin, there are scenarios where one user in particular is not interested in getting notified from JIRA on issue changes.

In such scenarios, JIRA requires that users be removed from groups that relate to the notification they do not have.

*Expected Result*
Customer would like to be able to tick an option in user management or configure from user profile to opt out of all notifications.

*Actual Result*
The Admin would need to remove the user from all groups and users associated with receiving various notifications.
- This is made more difficult if you try to remove users for a notification associated with group {{reporter}} or something similar.

*Workaround*
- Change the user's email address to a non valid email address.
(!) This however would prevent the user from getting all notifications and also prevent them from getting notification should they forget their password.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45937].
  {panel}

Right now, let's look at a scenario

JIRA Instance A
JIRA Core project: Core_project
User: Peter
Peter has the role 'User' in the Core_project

in the same instance, there is a 
JIRA Service Desk Project JSD_Project

User Peter has the customer role in that project.

Peter is assigned a task in Core_project and realizes he needs to get a user for the system first which he can request in the JSD_Project's customer portal. So he creates the service request and goes back to the Core_project and links the issue as 'is blocked by' to the JSD_project's issue key of his service request.

Now he can create the link - but then he doesn't see it because his user would need the 'browse project' permission of the JSD_Project.

Suggestion: Also, enable viewing of issue links to JSD tickets if they are visible to the user in the customer portal.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

h3. Summary
As part of JIRA Service Desk now, JIRA is storing the incoming mails in the database (done by the JEPP). Those are stored inside the *AO_2C4E5C_MAILITEMCHUNK* table.

JIRA is, sometimes, silently failing to import or export the active objects part of the backup.

\\
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install JIRA;
# Import the backup linked on the private comments.
# JIRA will stop importing once it reaches 90%. Restart JIRA.
# Navigate to *Administration » System » Plugin Data Storage* and verify what has been imported.

\\
h3. Expected Results
All entries in the active objects table would have been imported/exported.

\\
h3. Actual Results
* *Exporting:* JIRA creates the backup normally, but upon inspecting the {{activeobjects.xml}} file (using the grep below) not all entries are in the file.
* *Importing:* JIRA fails to import the data once it reaches 90%, but after restarting JIRA it seems to have imported correctly. Inspecting the *Plugin Data Storage* shows most tables as empty, and inspecting the {{activeobjects}} file shows all data.

(!) This seems to be happening because JIRA runs out of memory due to import, but fails to log any errors or warnings.

\\
h3. Notes
To verify the data inside the activeobjects.xml backup, run:
{code}
grep -E  "data tableName=|<row>" activeobjects.xml | uniq -c
{code}
This will show how many rows were exported for each table. For example, when JIRA failed to export correctly, this was shown:
{noformat}
      1   <data tableName="AO_21D670_WHITELIST_RULES">
      3     <row>
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILCHANNEL">
      1     <row>
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILCONNECTION">
      1     <row>
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILGLOBALHANDLER">
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILHANDLER">
      5     <row>
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILITEM">
   3625     <row>
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILITEMAUDIT">
   3625     <row>
      1   <data tableName="AO_2C4E5C_MAILITEMCHUNK">
    691     <row>
{noformat}
It is possible to see what tables were (supposed to be) exported to the backup with:
{noformat}
grep "table name=" activeobjects.xml
{noformat}

\\
h3.Workaround

*Follow our [Increasing JIRA Memory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Increasing+JIRA+Memory] guide to increase the memory available to JIRA, restart JIRA and try to import/export the backup again.* If this doesn't work, please follow the instructions below:

\\
*For importing:*
It is possible to remove the affected lines from the backup with:
# Run:
{code}grep -En  "data tableName=" activeobjects.xml | grep -A1 "MAILITEMCHUNK" | cut -d":" -f1{code}
This will return two numbers.
# use {{vim}} to open the activeobjects.xml and run:
{code}
:num1,num2s;<string>.*</string>;<string></string>;g
{code}
Where num1 and num2 are the numbers returned in the first step. e.g.:
{code}:45635,58649s;<string>.*</string>;<string></string>;g{code}
# save and exit vim;
# zip the backup again and import.

This will return the body of the emails that are stored.

\\
*To export:*
# Turn off the Email Puller so that no new mail will be added to the database
#* JIRA Administration > System > Global Mail Settings
# Wait at least 5 minutes so that the mail processor is able to process mail that is already in the database
# Stop JIRA;
# Run the following update in the database to delete the mail items:
#* Optional: backup this table using your database's native tools before running the update
{code:SQL}
UPDATE "AO_2C4E5C_MAILITEMCHUNK" SET "MIME_MSG_CHUNK" = NULL;
{code}
# Restart JIRA;
# Export the data again.
# Turn the Email Puller back on

Currently everytime user create a same project type in JIRA 7, the project will be using basic workflow scheme.

User would like JIRA to have option during project creation, when user select similar project type all of them using a specific workflow scheme for that specific project type. h3. Steps to Reproduce.
# Create a Workflow with new statuses.
# Assign it to a Workflow Scheme that Include JIRA Default Workflow and the new workflow.
# Assign the Issue types for the workflow, for example the New Workflow is for "New Feature" issue type.
# Create a new issue type scheme that exclude "New Feature" issue types.
# Create a new project with the newly created Issue Type Scheme and Workflow Scheme.
# Create several issues.
# Go to issue navigator and search for that specific project.
# Click on the Status button. 

h3. Desired Results:
Only status that is from JIRA Default Workflow will be listed.

h3. Current Results:
New statuses from the New Workflow will be included as well.

h3. Notes:
- It looks like the issue navigator will still be showing any status that is mentioned on the Workflows that is specified on the Workflow Scheme, even though it is not being used.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45840].
  {panel}

When creating a Project using the {{Create with shared configuration}} button on the Create Project screen, it could give the user the impression that the projects would have an ongoing connection of some kind, such as with JRA-7020.

However, the feature currently just "clones" the existing configuration. Because of this, it would be nice if the wording changed.

The button could change from {{Create with shared configuration}} to {{Clone Existing Project Configuration}} (similar to cloning plans/deployments in Bamboo).

In addition, the title of the next screen "Create with shared configuration" would read "Clone with existing project configuration".

In addition, the description of the next screen "Select the existing project that you'd like to share configurations with." would read "Select the existing project that you'd like to clone the configuration of."

In addition, the warning message "When a configuration is shared with several projects, it means that any changes made to the configuration will affect all the projects." on the next page could say "While project configuration schemes are shared between projects, it means that any changes made to the configuration will affect all the projects."

If this feature ever becomes similar to JRA-7020, this could be rolled back.
fields.summary: Change wording of "Shared Configuration" feature
Spam

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45836].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
The @mention feature of JIRA is failing to find some users (mostly ones with names starting with the initial letter of the domain) because the javascript responsible for this feature performs a filter over the results of a query via a REST call which is limited to 10 results. The REST call returns users which match the query string (username parameter in the rest call) based on if it exists in EITHER the username, display name, or email address. Because normally the domain matches many users email address, searching for users starting with the initial letter of the domain, will be filtered out. 
e.g: mike@mydomain.com may be filtered out when searching for m if there are many more users with @mydomain.com email address and at least 10 users alphabetically before mike.

h3. Environment
Affected version: 7.0.0-OD-08

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create 11 users with the same domain email address. eg: @example.com
# Name the first 10 users with Letters before e
# Name the 11th user 'example'
# Try to mention the user in a comment.

h3. Expected Results
If you use the complete username, or display name, the user should always appear.

h3. Actual Results
Using the complete username or display name, doesn't show the user because the rest api is returning 10 previous users (but not displaying them as options)

h3. Notes
When troubleshooting, take into consideration that you may need to refocus the comment box for the search to be done: [JRA-59304|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-59304]

h3. Workaround
*Partial workaround*
Try with a different user value (if you tried with username, try display name, or last name). The last name value works particularly well as it is quite unique.

*Confirmed workaround*
Typing the first few characters of a user's name and hitting the {{TAB}} button will autocomplete and allow for the user to be mentioned (until you refresh the page) _e.g. John = Joh...{{TAB}}_
fields.summary: Some JIRA '@mentions' are not showing all users due JavaScript and REST APIs filters

h3. Summary
As mentioned at [Change Site Logo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/change-your-site-logo-and-colors-744721608.html#Changeyoursitelogoandcolors-Changethesitelogo], user should be able to revert the color scheme if they don't like it. Once the logo is changed, clicking *Undo* button does not revert the color scheme.
{quote}
We'll automatically change the colour scheme to match your logo, and if you like it, there's nothing more you need to do. We'll give you the option to undo the colour change with a single click, just in case you're not happy with the result.
{quote}

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Go to _Look and Feel_ configuration
# Change the logo with different background color (othen than blue)
# The color scheme will be changed to match the logo's color
# There will be notification message to offer users to _Undo_ it
#* {{We've updated the color scheme to match your logo. Undo.}} 
# Click on _Undo_ button

h3. Expected Result
The color scheme should be reverted back 

h3. Current Result
The color scheme remains the same

h3.NOTES:
in testing the custom color code applied that is changed when the logo is uploaded cannot be reset to the same value:
exe: if you set Header background color to {{#ff03ee}} and it is reset when the logo is uploaded reseting it to {{#ff03ee}} will not change the color BUT any other color i.e. {{#ff03ed}} or {{#ff03ef}} will allocate the change.

h3.Workaround:
# Note all custom color codes applied manually
#* i.e.{{#ff03ee}}
# Select Reset to default and all jira default colors are applied and logo removed
# Upload the Custom Site Logo While Default colors are set
# Do not select the undo option when automatic color change is applied
# Manually re-apply custom color values to the desired values you noted initially
fields.summary: Unable to revert the color scheme after changing logo

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45826].
  {panel}

h5. Problem Definition
At the moment, upgrading JIRA using installer will perform the following:
# Creating backup of the installation directory
# Deleting the installation directory
# Extracting the installer, and so on

When extracting the installer, it will check the available memory space. If user does not have enough space, user is required to cancel the upgrading process half way. By doing so, the next time user tries to upgrade, he will lose the "upgrade" option, and will be presented with new installation instead, since the installation directory has been deleted during the initial attempt.

h5. Suggested Solution
JIRA should check the memory space available before proceeding with the upgrading process (deleting the installation directory, and so on)
fields.summary: JIRA installer should check memory space available before proceeding with upgrading steps
Flexibility to change the directory where attachments are stored

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45820].
  {panel}

After a recent issue with upgrading JIRA (where older Java version was not supported anymore), I was surprised that the JIRA installer did not check for prerequisites during installation (I am talking about Windows installer upgrading an existing installation). It's my fault completely for failing to read the supported platforms page at all, but nevertheless it would still be nice to prevent people from shooting themselves in the foot (and possibly reducing number of support requests in the long run).

There are at least two places I can think of where a "fail fast" approach would be of more help:

1. JIRA Installer should check which Java version is installed and fail if it is not supported.
2. Batch scripts for the JIRA service installation should *not* try to guess the JIRA path, but instead fail immediately if {{JRE_HOME}} and {{JAVA_HOME}} are not defined. Otherwise it's easy to get the incorrect Java instance running for the Tomcat service, even though there are no warnings during installation. Right now the script checks {{JRE_HOME}}, then {{JAVA_HOME}} and then defaults to a bundled JRE installation (and the resulting folder looks "funny" like described [here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/31662205/answers/31663637]).

Finally, docs on configuring {{JAVA_HOME}} should be clarified to remove ambiguities. All over the Atlassian site, it's suggested to define {{JAVA_HOME}} to point to Java *JRE* folder. On the other hand, if you install Bamboo, it requires that {{JAVA_HOME}} is pointing to Java *JDK*. Even the batch script which installs JIRA as a service first checks if {{JRE_HOME}} is defined, instead of {{JAVA_HOME}}.

It seems a correct setup would be:
- {{JAVA_HOME}} - points to JDK (needed for Bamboo, and not needed at all if you are only running JIRA),
- {{JRE_HOME}} - points to JRE (also including the bundled JRE)
- service scripts checks if they are indeed pointing to correct folders and fails as soon as one of these variables is configured incorrectly.
fields.summary: JIRA setup should perform more "sanity checks" before installing
